sections.content: Your Honor, we are here today to present evidence showing that the defendant breached the contract. The evidence will show clear violations of sections 3.2 and 4.1 of the agreement.
Thank you, counsel. Please proceed with your opening statement.
Objection, Your Honor. The plaintiff's characterization of the contract terms is misleading and prejudicial.
Overruled. This is opening statements. You'll have your opportunity to present your interpretation.
I was present during the contract negotiations. The defendant explicitly agreed to the delivery timeline of 30 days. There was no ambiguity in the terms discussed.
Mr. Davis, isn't it true that there were subsequent emails discussing potential modifications to that timeline?
There were discussions, yes, but no formal amendments were ever executed.
Objection. The witness is offering a legal conclusion about what constitutes a formal amendment.
Sustained. The jury will disregard the witness's characterization of formal amendments.
Mr. Davis, focusing just on what you observed, were any written modifications to the contract ever signed by both parties?
